Gerber Products Company is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68.  In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.

Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety.

Gerber Products Company is located at 405 West State Street, Fremont, Michigan. The facility includes processing tanks, piping, packaging equipment, raw materials warehousing, finished goods refrigerated storage, an Ammonia refrigeration engine room, boilers, and miscellaneous utilities.  

The refrigeration system required for our production process necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan.  The refrigeration system contains in excess of 16,400 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  This surpasses the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.

Gerber Products Company has implemented numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid property damage.

Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at our facility.

Process Hazard Analysis was recently completely in April of 2004.  These Process Hazard Analysis  highl

ighted some deficiencies in the system. These items are being addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. These items were addressed on the basis of risk rating (Injuries to personnel). Items of a low priority (Process improvements) were budgeted for completion in a timely manner.

Gerber Products Company ammonia refrigeration system also incorporates additional safety items such as tagging of all valves and components, and a PC / PLC based control system with a graphical operator interface that controls mitigating devices such as emergency exhaust fans, emergency shutdown systems and alarms.

Refrigeration Process Description

The Gerber Products Co., Fremont Michigan incorporates a standard evaporation and Compression Style Ammonia Refrigeration system.  Ammonia vapor, High Stage Suction, (HSS) from the 30?F High Temperature Suction Accumulator (V-15) is routed to the suction inlet of four High Stage Screw Compressors (HS-1, HS-2, HS-3, and HS-4).  

At the High Stage Compressors (HS-1, HS-2, HS-3, and HS-4), ammonia vapor (HSS) is compressed to a super heated vapor (HSD).  The super heated vapor (HSD) from the High Stage Compressors (HS-1, HS-2, HS-3, and HS-4) is routed from the Machine Room to the roof.  On the roof it is fed to an Evaporative Condensers (EC1, EC2, and EC3).  At the Condensers the super heated vapor (HSD) rejects heat and converts to high pressure Condensed Liquid Drain (CD).  The condenser accomplishes this by using a combination of air and water flow across ammonia coils.  The condensers are equipped with Safety Relief Valves, which vent directly to atmosphere.  Air flow is supplied to the condensers via fans internal to the condenser.  Water is supplied by Condensers (EC1, EC2, and EC3) via a Water Pumps.  

Water from the Condenser Water Sump is pumped via a Water Pumps to the Evaporative Condensers (EC1, EC2, and EC3).  At the Condenser the water is sprayed via a spray header over the ammonia coils.  Water is collected

at the bottom of the Condenser in a sump pan where it gravity drains back to the Condenser Water Sump.  From here it is recirculated back to the condensers.  As the water level of the Condenser Water Sump lowers it trips a Water Makeup Float which opens allowing water makeup to refill the Condenser Sump Tank.  The Condenser Water Sump is also equipped with a water treatment for the control of contaminates in the water system.  

The Condensed Liquid Drain (CD) from the Evaporative Condensers (EC1, EC2, and EC3) gravity drains to the Thermosyphon vessel (V17) and the High Pressure Receiver (V16).  

High Pressure Liquid (TSS) gravity drains from the Thermosyphon vessel (V13) portion of the High Pressure Receiver (V-16) to Thermosyphon Supply Headers which supply liquid to the Thermosyphon Oil Coolers of the High Stage Compressors (HS-1, HS-2, HS-3, and HS-4) and the Low Stage Compressors (LS1 and LS2).  At the Thermosyphon Oil Coolers on the Compressors (HS1, HS2, HS3, HS4, LS1, and LS2) the High Pressure Liquid (TSS) absorbs heat from the oil pumped through the Compressor.  As it absorbs heat it changes from a liquid (TSS) to a Liquid/Vapor Combination (TSR).  This Liquid Vapor Combination (TSR) is returned from the Thermosyphon Oil Cooler on each Compressor (HS1, HS2, HS3, HS4, LS1, and LS2) to the Thermosyphon Return Header (TSR) where it returns to the Thermosyphon vessel (V17).  In the Thermosyphon vessel (V17) the liquid and vapor is separated.  The liquid being recirculated back out to the Compressors through the Thermosyphon supply main.  The Vapor (EQL) is returned to the top of the High Stage Discharge Main on the roof where it ties back into the High Stage Discharge Header, and is fed to the Evaporative Condensers (EC1, EC2, and EC3).  Here it is re-condensed into a High Pressure Liquid (CD) and returned to the Thermosyphon vessel and the High Pressure Receiver (V16).  

As liquid accumulates in the Thermosyphon vessel (V17) it will overfill the and gravi

ty drain back into the High Pressure Receiver (V16) is used as a storage vessel for Ammonia Liquid (HPL).  As Ammonia Liquid (HPL) is needed in the system, it is fed (by a pressure) from the High Pressure Receiver (V16) through a King solenoid valve and is used in the system for liquid (HPL) makeup to High Temperature Accumulator (V15).

High Pressure Liquid (HPL) is fed to the Auto Purger (RPU).  Purged Gas (PUR) is piped from the Purged Points to the Auto Purger (RPU).  This system has a multiple purge points. The Evaporative Condensers (EC1, EC2, and EC3) has two Purge Points on the Condensed Liquid Drain Outlets.  Each Purge Point consists of a solenoid valve with shutoff valves on either side for isolation.  Any non-condensibles in the Vapor Stream are removed periodically by the Automatic Purger (RPU).  The Purge Gas (PUR) is separated by the Automatic Gas Purger (RPU).  Its separates ammonia from the non-condensibles by condenses the ammonia into a liquid.  Any non-condensibles are piped to a Water Bubbler to remove any traces of ammonia.  Condensed Vapor (LSS) is piped back to the ?20 F Low Temperature Accumulator (V14) Suction Main (LTRS) and thus back to the ?20 F Low Temperature Accumulator (V14).  

The system is equipped with a Heat Exchanger which heats a glycol solution.  The glycol solution is then piped under the freezer floors to prevent a buildup of permafrost.  This Heat Exchanger (V13) utilizes High Stage Discharge (HSD) which is a high temperature compressed vapor.  This vapor enters the Heat Exchanger via a solenoid valve.  In the Heat Exchanger the vapor rejects heat thus condensing to a liquid where it collects on the bottom of the Heat Exchanger and gravity drains to a liquid drainer.  As the liquid drainer becomes full it will dump the liquid back into the High Stage Suction Main where it is returned to 30 F High Temperature Suction Accumulator (V-15).

Low Temperature Recirculated Liquid (LTRL) that has been pumped from the ?20 F Low Temp

erature Accumulator (V14) is pumped through Freezer A evaporator AB and Freezer B evaporators BA and BB.  The (LTRL) passed through a shutoff valve, then an electric solenoid shutoff valve, then a check valve, then a shutoff valve, and the a hand expansion valve (HEV) where the liquid is expanded where it undergoes a deliberate change in pressure and temperature then into the Evaporator Coil.  While in the coil it absorbs heat from the air and changes from a Liquid (LTRL) to a Liquid/Vapor Combination (LTRS).  As the Liquid/Vapor Combination (LTRS) exits the coil it passes through a gas powered stop check valve then through a shutoff valve and then back to the Low Temperature Recirculated Main (LTRS).  These Evaporators (AB, BA, and BB) are equipped with a hot gas circuit.  The Hot Gas (HSD) which is at high temperature is pumped via pressure to the coil.  At the coil it passes through a shutoff valve, part of the gas is used to power the stop check valve closed in the suction line, this is only during defrost operations.  The remainder of the hot gas passes through a hot gas regulator into the coil pan where it defrosts the coil pan at this point the electric solenoid in the Low Temperature Recirculated Liquid (LTRL) Inlet is closed therefore the hot gas travels through the pan and then through the coil, out of the coil through a float drainer, through a check valve and shutoff valve it is returned to the Low Temperature Recirculated Suction (LTRS) main and thus back to the -20 F Low Temperature Accumulator (V14).  This unit is equipped with a solenoid bypass of the gas powered stop valve, this allows for  bleeding of pressure from the coil to the Low Temperature Recirculated Suction Main prior to opening the stop check.

High Temperature Recirculated Liquid (HTRL) that has been pumped from the 30 F High Temperature Accumulator (V15) is pumped through Coolers CA, CB, DA, DB, EA, EB, FA, FB, GA, GB, H, I and Hallway evaporators TAA and TAB. The (HTRL) passed through

a shutoff valve, then an electric solenoid shutoff valve, then a check valve, then a shutoff valve, and the a hand expansion valve (HEV) where the liquid is expanded where it undergoes a deliberate change in pressure and temperature then into the Evaporator Coil.  While in the coil it absorbs heat from the air and changes from a Liquid (HTRL) to a Liquid/Vapor Combination (LTRS).  As the Liquid/Vapor Combination (HTRS) exits the coil it passes through a gas powered stop check valve then through a shutoff valve and then back to the High Temperature Recirculated Main (HTRS).  These Evaporators  are equipped with a hot gas circuit.  The Hot Gas (HSD) which is at high temperature is pumped via pressure to the coil.  At the coil it passes through a shutoff valve, part of the gas is used to power the stop check valve closed in the suction line, this is only during defrost operations.  The remainder of the hot gas passes through a hot gas regulator into the coil pan where it defrosts the coil pan at this point the electric solenoid in the High Temperature Recirculated Liquid (HTRL) Inlet is closed therefore the hot gas travels through the pan and then through the coil, out of the coil through a float drainer, through a check valve and shutoff valve it is returned to the High Temperature Recirculated Suction (HTRS) main and thus back to the 30 F High Temperature Accumulator (V15).  This unit is equipped with a solenoid bypass of the gas powered stop valve, this allows for bleeding of pressure from the coil to the High Temperature Recirculated Suction Main prior to opening the stop check.


Summary of The Five-Year Accident History

Gerber Products Company has had no reportable accidents in the last five years involving ammonia.

Description of the Emergency Response Plan

Purpose:     
This Procedure is written to help ensure the safety and protection of our employees, responders, neighbors and environment in the event of a chemical release emergency.  In addition this proced

ure provides a structured response to mitigating the emergency and ensures compliance with both Occupational Health & Safety and Environmental Protection regulations.

Scope:
This procedure applies to all activities at the Gerber Products Company Fremont Site, and includes releases of hazardous or polluting materials.  Those materials include but are not limited to; anhydrous ammonia, caustic & acid based cleaners, petroleum and vegetable oils, paints and paint solvents, pesticides, water treatment chemicals, process chemicals, cleaners containing sodium hypochlorite, hydrogen peroxide and hazardous wastes.
This procedure does not apply to incidental spills or releases that may be mitigated by operators or supervision.

Responsibility:
Annual review and subsequent updates to this plan are the responsibility of the Fremont HSEO
It is the responsibility of the emergency response team (ERT) to respond and mitigate all chemical release emergencies resulting from activities or uses of chemicals at the Fremont site.

Reference:
MIOSHA Part 91 Rule 408.491
OSHA 1910.120
Novartis Guideline #2 Novartis Emergency Management (NEM)

Procedure: 

Pre-emergency planning
Chemical emergency response training is provided to each member of the emergency response team (ERT).  Hazardous material technician level (24 hour) training is provided to those team members who will be directly involved in mitigation, clean up or decontamination activities.  Trainers and training materials shall meet State requirements for technician level.  Annual refresher training and periodic practice drills are provided to keep ERT skills current. 

Local Emergency response and health care organizations are included in the practice drills.  Inspections of chemical storage areas and process systems are offered annually to the local

fire department.

Personnel Roles
In the event of a chemical release the Gerber ERT will be dispatched to assess, mitigate and clean up the release.  The incident command system will be put into place.  Members of the ERT have completed IC training.  Should additional resources be needed the ERT will request site security to call 911 for assistance from local fire departments and/or medical services.
The site Novartis Emergency Management Team (NEM) will assume an additional support and management role.  This role will include resource allocation, logistics, data, documentation, and communications both internal and external.

Recognition and Prevention
Employees are trained to recognize a chemical emergency during their job orientation and hazard communication training.  Employees and supervisors are instructed to call for the ERT if a release cannot be contained without potential exposure.  Between Gerber employees and site security, chemical process systems and chemical storage are monitored around the clock seven days a week (24/7).  Preventative maintenance is performed on the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.  The site has a Risk Management Plan and a Process Safety Management Plan for the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.

Safe distances and places of refuge
In the event of a chemical release inside a building, which has the potential to create an unsafe atmosphere, the building will be evacuated.  In the event that the chemical release would not pose an inhalation hazard, the area of the spill and an appropriate buffer zone will be evacuated until the spill can be cleaned up. Should a site wide chemical emergency occur, the maintenance departments will shut down air handling systems as needed.  In the event of an exterior exposure the employees will be directed to the unexposed side of the building for sheltering in place in the event of an exterior exposure or a full evacuation if the exposure is interior.
Air monitoring, wind direction and relea

se rates shall determine safe distances and locations.

Site security and control
The Fremont Campus is monitored 24/7 by a contracted security firm.  During a chemical emergency security shall be used to ensure that effected areas are kept clear of unauthorized individuals. Supplemental security may also be provided by supervisors and ERT.  Access to an emergency scene is limited to members of the ERT and local emergency resources that may have been requested.

Evacuation routes and procedures
Evacuation routes are posted for sheltering in place and evacuation from buildings.  Supervisors are responsible for assisting in the evacuation and determining that all employees are accounted for. 
Processes that could pose further danger if left unattended will be shut down according to emergency shut down procedures prior to operators evacuating (if the procedure can be performed without risk of exposure to the operator).  Evacuation drills are practiced annually and evacuation routes are reviewed for effectiveness.  
Safe areas will always be upwind of the release.

Decontamination 
Decontamination of people, property and personal protective equipment is the responsibility of the ERT and is performed after a chemical release clean up. Decontamination water is neutralized or contained and treated as hazardous waste in accordance with hazardous waste regulations.  Decontamination is performed by Gerber employees trained in decontamination procedures with assistance from the local fire department as needed.  Decontamination occurs as people and property leave the contaminated area and after the clean up is complete. 

Medical treatment and First Aid
Any Gerber Products Co. employee who is over exposed to inhalation chemical levels will be sent for medical evaluation and treatment.  Any Gerber Products Co. employee who physically contacts chemicals will be decontaminated and treated as needed.  First aid is available on site from trained individuals.  If any further treatmen

t is needed, individuals will be sent to Gerber Memorial Hospital.  

Emergency alerting and response procedure
Employees working in an area with a chemical spill or release are instructed to notify site security by calling the internal emergency number 62233.  Witnessing a release may include hearing an alarm from a sensing monitor.
Upon being notified security will utilize the public address system to dispatch the emergency response team, and to notify employees on the type of emergency and provide further instructions. 
Should a chemical release have the potential to migrate off Gerber property individuals in the community adjacent to the property will be alerted.  Relevant data will be supplied to the police department by the site HSEO or his designee.  The police department will then have the task of notifying the effected community.

Critique of response and follow up
As soon as possible following a response to a chemical release a team will convene to critique the response.  The team will be composed of members of management, ERT and the affected operations.  The purpose of the critique is to gather data for performance improvement should another event occur.  In addition the root cause or causes of the release will be investigated to provide corrective measures to prevent future releases.

PPE and emergency equipment
Emergency equipment for response to chemical releases is stored in a controlled area and is inspected at least monthly and after each use.  Equipment is removed from service should anything be found during an inspection that could negatively effect the use of the equipment.  Removing equipment from service includes attaching a red tag with the date, name of person tagging equipment and the reason for removing the equipment from service. The HSE department keeps records of inspections and servicing.
Responders are fit tested for self-contained breathing apparatus annually and are included in the respiratory protection program for tight fitting re

spirators.  The responders are trained in the use and limitations of their equipment and PPE.  The HSE department maintains training records.

Conclusion

Gerber Products Company is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of Gerber Products Company to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system to insure the safety of the personnel, environment, and the product.
